author: George A. King III
title: Harmless pop-up turns into disaster as Jays fall in 0-2 ALCS hole
text:
KANSAS CITY — A bloop single by Ben Zobrist to start the seventh inning looked innocent but became turned deadly for the Blue Jays and moved the Royals closer to a second straight World Series date.
With David Price on his way to shredding the reputation of being an October liability and nine outs away from the Blue Jays tying the best-of-seven ALCS with a Game 2 victory over the Royals at Kauffman Stadium Saturday, Price and the visitors flushed a lead and inhaled on a horrifying 6-3 loss in front of a sold-out and delirious crowd of 40,357.
Price had a 3-0 cushion to start the seventh, had allowed one hit, didn’t face a batter with a runner in scoring position and retired 18 straight after Alcides Escobar’s single to start the home first.
By the time the inning was over, the Royals had scored five runs — all charged to Price — and on the way to taking a 2-0 bulge to Toronto where Game 3 will be played Monday night at Rogers Centre.
Johnny Cueto starts for the Royals, and Marcus Stroman goes for the Blue Jays.
It’s the second straight post-season series the Blue Jays have lost the first two games. They rebounded to beat the Rangers three straight to win the ALDS and have five chances to win four and advance to the World Series for the first time since 1993.
The Royals are two wins away from returning to the World Series for the second straight year. They took the Giants to seven games in last season’s Series and lost.
Ben Zobrist’s bloop single to right field leading off the seventh that was botched by second baseman Ryan Goins and right fielder Jose Bautista who failed to catch it gave the crowd hope that increased when Lorenzo Cain singled sharply to right.
Eric Hosmer delivered an RBI single to center that scored Zobrist and sent Hosmer to third.
With runners at the corners, Kendrys Morales’ grounder up the middle was caught by shortstop Troy Tulowitzki and turned into an out at first as Cain scored and Hosmer went to second.
With the Blue Jays’ lead whittled to 3-2, Price faced the left-handed hitting Mike Moustakas with one out and the potential tying run on second. Moustakas’ single to right plated Hosmer to tie the score, 3-3, and he took second on Jose Bautista’s off-line throw to the plate. The hit stopped a 0-for-13 hitless slide for Moustakas.
At 80 pitches, Price started working on Salvador Perez and caught him looking at a 3-2 pitch for the second out. That brought the left-handed hitting Alex Gordon to the plate. His 0-for-2 lowered the lifetime average against Price to .186 (3-for-16) but was raised with a double to right-center that scored Moustakas for a 4-3 lead.
Gordon was the final batter Price faced, replaced by Aaron Sanchez who gave up an RBI single to Alex Rios that upped the lead to 5-3.
The immediate reason Price was imported from Detroit at the trade deadline to Toronto was so the Blue Jays could get past the Yankees and win the AL East.
Beyond that the Blue Jays believed the large lefty would provide them an ace if they got to the postseason regardless of a poor post-season résumé.
Price filled the bill in the first department delivered in the second category through six innings Saturday.
Millions of words have been written and spoken about Price’s miserable post-season statistics and had painted a Cy Young-like season as secondary. However, Blue Jays manager John Gibbons didn’t buy the noise.
“I don’t give a thought what he’s done in the postseason,’’ Gibbons said. “I’ve seen him. He’s been a key guy getting us here. I look forward to every time he’s taking the mound.’’
With the usually potent Blue Jays offense not producing slow-pitch softball numbers for the second straight game it was up to Price to get the visitors even and he didn’t.
In 6 ²/₃ innings, Price allowed five runs and six hits. In 13 post-season games (seven starts) the free agent-to- be is 2-7 with a hefty 5.24 ERA.
